choices: Describe the conference room and mood
1.content: The Chaser is sitting in the conference room being briefed about the fugitive.
1.title: Begin

11.content: "You must infiltrate the organization." states the Director. "We have been unable to get a lead in this vigilante group."
11.title: fugitive briefing

111.content:
"What have you done so far?" asked the Chaser.

The Director pulled out a crumpled pack of Marlboros and offered one to the Chaser. They lit up.

"Now that you have taken some time to filter it," said the Chaser, "what do you have for me?" He blew a smoke ring at the ceiling, but kept his eyes on the Director's face.

"We sent two teams so far. We sent Jesse and Doc three months back. They have not been heard from since. Bonnie and Clyde went ten days ago. There has been no word from them since they went deep. Both teams were to report on alternate days. We fear the worst."

The Director had used code words, as was SOP. The Chaser had worked with two of the agents mentioned, and they had been very good.

"Our only possible lead is a bar on the Wharf," continued the Director. "We suspect it is used as a meeting point for the vigilantes, and we suspect the barman is in on it. We have nothing definite, however."

"What's the name of the bar?" asked the Chaser.

"The Brass Bass. The barman calls himself Patrick 'Knuckles' McCain. It is an assumed name, and we have not been able to dig up anything yet. We suspect he's ex-IRA."

The Chaser nodded, and mused for a while. "Anything else?" he asked.

"No," said the Director.

"Let me work this alone for a while," said the Chaser. "I will let you know if I need a partner or team."

The Director looked like he was going to object, and then held his tongue.

"OK," he said, "but you will report in every day."
111.title: Improve or elaborate on the briefing

1111.content: The chaser stood up "you must kill your closest friend or we kill you"
1111.title: Death or not?

1112.content:
As the Chaser is about to close the door, the director yells, "One more thing!"

"This vigilante group is unlike your typical group. They are sympathizers and nonviolent. Their motivation is to protect certain Hate speech criminals against the justice they deserve. They help them get out of the state." Explains the director, "They think Hate speech is not a crime."

"What's the rules of engagement, sir?" Asks the Chaser.

"Few people have any sympathy for these fanatics. You may fire if they flee after your resist. Do not shoot to kill, but -", answers the director. The Chaser understood that meant a kill would not be questioned.

The Chaser drove to The Brass Bass. He used to hate going to bars because of the thick cigarette smoke. That was no problem anymore with the new Ohio law banning smoking in all public places. He smirked thinking about the director's lack of respect for the ban in the police station.
1112.title: One more thing - About the vigilante group

11121.content:
The Chaser calls Fred, his best informant, on his cell phone and they agree to meet at The Brass Bass.

Fifteen minutes later, The Chaser parks his black Lincoln on the Miami Avenue a block south from the bar. The Brass Bass is a small neighborhood bar and true to its name there is a lunker largemouth bass imprisoned in brass behind the bar.

The Chaser strolls into the bar, adjusts his eyes to the dim lighting, and sees Fred sitting in a corner booth already working on a beer.
11121.title: The Brass Bass

choices: What did the Chaser ask Fred to do?
111212.content:
Fred is a diminutive man, probably because of the Asian portion of the tripartite blood in him. His mother was a South Vietnamese government official's daughter and his father, Arnold, an Army clerk who had been posted to Saigon. Arnold's father was of Irish descent, and his mother a Mexican aristocrat.

Arnold had fallen love with Fred's mother at their very first meeting at a Christmas Eve dinner. He had assiduously wood her, and succeeded. They were married after a courtship of almost one year. Fred was born in the States two years later.

Fred was wearing a checked flannel shirt hanging loose over a pair of jeans. He had put on his favourite cowboy boots - something that was almost a fetish with him. He had taken off his jacket, which was hanging over the back of his chair, and as usual, he looked alert and attentive, even though his eyes were hidden behind dark glasses.

"Do you sleep wearing those shades?" asked the Chaser by way of greeting.

Fred lifted a hand, gestured to the chair in front of him and said, "Not these. I have got another pair for sleeping."

Fred was small, but he was tough. He hid a core of steel under a ready smile that lit up his handsome face. He wore his jet black hair down to his shoulders, tied in a pony tail at the back. He looked at the Chaser with an eyebrow raised.

"I don't suppose you wanted to meet me to discuss my shades, did you? Why don't you order some drinks and tell me what it is all about."
111212.title: Description of informant

choices: Chaser works through other means to blow Fugitive’s cover.
Fred is able to give the pill to the rowdy one in the backroom.
1112121.content:
Just then, they heard a car backfire outside the bar. A rock slammed at the bar window, bringing down the glass in shards. The customers sitting near the window booths scattered rapidly.

“What in the world’s going on?” Someone yelled.

Fred stood up, but Chaser motioned him to sit down. “Wait!” He ordered.

They saw the barman pick up the phone and dial a number while the customers settled down.

“Some drunken rowdiness,” Chaser said slowly. “They’ll soon bring inside the unruly one to hide him from the police. When they do that, I want you go after them and offer your help. Say you’re a medic and give one of these to the criminal to swallow.”

“Why can’t they understand small crimes breed bigger ones?” Fred mumbled.

Chaser took his hand out of his pocket and placed it on the table. Fred planted his hand over Chaser’s in a friendly gesture. After Chaser pulled his hand back, Fred dragged his hand slowly and put it in his pocket.

“You planted him, didn’t you?” Fred whispered. “The rowdy drunk who broke the window…He’s your snitch!”

Chaser nodded. “What he swallows will be a microchip. There are five microchips in pill form in that tiny box. It will stay in his system for two days, and if we’re lucky, longer. I want you trace him, follow him, and supply him with more chips until they take him to their holding point. We need to know where they are holding these law breakers.”

“Why didn’t you give him the whole thing?” Fred asked, adjusting his dark glasses over his nose. “Wouldn’t that be easier?”

“The Fugitive searches them every step of the way. His cover would be blown, if they found the chips on him.”

At the same time the barmaid thunked two beers in front of them, two men carrying the rowdy drunk entered inside the bar, rushing their way to the backroom. Chaser didn’t look at them, but he took a bottle and poured the beer into his glass. Fred stood up and went after the men.

Chaser heard his voice faintly. “Let me help. I am an EMT guy,” he was saying.

Chaser sipped his beer slowly, then stood up leaving a twenty on the table. One snitch might not cut it. He had to fortify this lead with others. While Fred would be covering this area, Chaser could get to the heart of the matter through other means.
1112121.title: What did the Chaser ask Fred to do?

choices: What was the message sent by the Chaser?
Who were the three recipients of the message?
11121211.content:
The Chaser drove to his room and pulled his laptop out from under his bed. He plugged it in and put it on. He booted using a complicated series of passwords.

He logged in on his cellphone, and accessed his email account. He pondered on the message that had been playing in his head since he was at the Brass Bass, and he made several mental changes before he was satisfied with the result.

He sent the same message to three email accounts using a rerouter that would leave no trace whatsoever of the origin of the messages. He asked the recipients for some very specific information. He knew they would reply, and they would reply using very secure connections.

He hoped at least one of the replies would give him a strong lead on the Fugitive.
11121211.title: Chaser emails three contacts

choices: What was the response of the other two contacts?
What did the Chaser decide to do about the Gladiator?
111212111.content:
The Chaser had sent the same coded message to all three of his contacts.

He had asked for all known information about the Fugitive. He had asked for all known facts about those involved, any addresses and contact details, any info on modus operandi and working patterns.

He had offered a reward of at least a thousand bucks, and more depending on the value of the information. He knew his contacts would trust him on this: they had done business with him before and he had never let them down before.

He especially wanted to know: who was really the Fugitive? Who was the mastermind behind Fugitive.

He was astonished to receive a reply from one of his contacts, a Moroccan who operated under the name of The Gladiator, in less than five minutes.

The Gladiator simply said, "Lay Off. Don't contact me on this again."

The Chaser's curiosity was piqued.
111212111.title: What was the message sent by the Chaser?

choices: Back to Fred at the Brass Bass
1112121111.content:
The second response on The Chaser's cell was from Dutch,
         The organization has many cells with no head

The last informant, Candy, responded,
         Go undercover - Joey at the bus station - 333 bus to Cleveland.
1112121111.title: Response of the other two contacts

11121211111.content:
The Chaser entered the old bus station and saw one young man at the counter and only a few passengers sitting around waiting for their ride. As he approached he saw that his name tag was Joey. He looked up at the board and saw that there was a 2:11 and 4:52 bus to Cleveland but no 3:33. He suspected as much.

"333 to Cleveland," he said boldly but only loud enough for Joey to hear.
11121211111.title: Undercover: 333 bus

choices: What name is on the fake ID?
What bus did Joey put the Chaser on?
111212111111.content:
Joey looked at the Chaser for a moment, checking him out. Then he said, "ID please".

Chase kept his badge in his pocket and pulled out one of his fake ID's.
111212111111.title: Undercover: Response to 333 bus request

1112121111112.content:
Joey checks out the ID and responds, "Here's your ticket Mr. Jones. That'll be $18."

The Chaser pays for the ticket and thanks him.

As he heads to the buses, he checks his ticket. It was a 2:11 ticket for Cleveland. With the ticket is a postcard.

The postcard reads
         Exit with female in Browns jacket

The Chaser steps onto the bus. He looks around at the other passengers but doesn't notice anyone with a Browns jacket. He takes a seat near the front so that he can exit quickly.

Just before the bus is to take off, a young woman gets on the bus and sits across the aisle from him. She was a short black woman with blond dread-locks and wore a Cleveland Browns jacket. He smiled. He thought it strange because the woman could hardly go unnoticed.

The bus driver closed the door and announced, "Next stop, Akron. Estimated ride time is one hour 10 minutes," and the bus left the station.

The ride was uneventful as they took the interstate and a short ride downtown Akron to the station on Grant street.

She hadn't acknowledged him when they exited the bus. He thought it was not supposed to look like he was following her since this was an underground organization.

The Chaser followed the woman in the Browns jacket as she walked north on Grant Street. They passed under the interstate and cut through an industrial complex.
1112121111112.title: Undercover: Bus Ride

11121211111121.content:
"Go to that church. Sit in the second pew on the far right," she finally broke the silence and then headed in another direction.

He quickened his pace and in a couple minutes entered the vestibule of the church. It was a small, simple church without the expensive accouterments of the larger churches. He opened the door to the main auditorium and noticed a middle-aged Hispanic woman sitting in the second pew.

He nodded at the woman as he sat next to her.
11121211111121.title: Second pew

111212111111211.content:
The woman's purse started buzzing. She removed her cell phone from her purse, stood and exited the auditorium.

In the vestibule, she looked at her phone call. On the screen was a picture of the man that has sat beside her in the pew. Along with the picture was a text message.

         Jason Locke, Level 2, Set A

Level 2 described his alleged crime. Set A described his background check. In this case it meant high confidence that he was legit.

She takes quick strides back to the second pew to help Jason Locke.
111212111111211.title: woman's reaction positive

11121212.content:
"You will be sore for a few days but nothing's broken," Fred tells the rowdy one as he pulls another piece of glass from his back.

"Thanks, Doctor." The rowdy one says as he grimaces from the pain.

"Just call me Fred. Take these two pills. It'll take the edge off the pain." Fred hands him the pills and the rowdy one swallows them. Fred hands him his card and says, "Call me in a couple days and I'll make a house call."

"Thanks again, Fred. Friends call me Silver."
11121212.title: Fred gives tracking pill to the rowdy one ...

info.brief_description: Marshal to bust up fugitive-aiding organization. GPs for good additions.
info.description:
The "fugitive" is not one person but a nonviolent organization that sympathizes with a special group of "criminals" by setting up a 21st century version of an "Underground Railroad".

The Chaser works alone but can call on informants and call in calvary when it becomes necessary.

In one path, he goes undercover.

Help define the Chaser, the "criminal" organization, and describe the chase.
